taxonConcepts.nameAccordingTo: Species 2000 & ITIS Catalogue of Life: April 2013

taxonConcepts.scientificName: Astronotus ocellatus (Agassiz in Spix and Agassiz, 1831)
Astronotus ocellatus (Agassiz in Spix and Agassiz, 1831)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObjects.description: Astronotus ocellatus is a species of fish from the cichlid family, originally described by Louis Agassiz in 1831, although he mistakenly classified it in the marine genus Lobotes. The largest of the new world cichlids, they can live 10-20 years and reach up to a maximum length of 45cm (18 inches) long, although they are most commonly found 25-30 cm (10-12 inches) in length and 1.6 kilograms (3.5 lb) in weight. A popular aquarium fish, Astronotus ocellatus has many common names, including oscar, tiger oscar, velvet cichlid, or marble cichlid, which reflect a number of bred ornamental varieties, including long-finned varieties and various color morphs. Oscars are native to the Amazon river basin, especially shallow, quiet floodplains and swamps. Native oscars usually show characteristic orange ringed, bilateral ocelli (eyespots) at the base of their tail which have been shown to dissuade predators and also function in sexual selection, as these fish are very visually oriented. Suction feeders, A. ocellatus are omnivorous, eating invertebrates such as flies, worms, crayfish, some small fish, fruit that falls into water, and large oscars will even eat small vertebrates, such as mice. Oscars are an esteemed food species in South America, although not commonly eaten elsewhere, as they grow too slowly for aquaculture. Escaped ornamentals and individuals purposely introduced into waterways have established wild populations in Asia, China and North America. (Beeching, 1995; Froese 2011; Griffioen 1999; Nico and Fuller 2012; Robbins; Wikipedia 2012; Winemiller 1990)
references: Beeching, SC, 1995. "Colour pattern and inhibition of aggression in the cichlid fish Astronotus ocellatus". Journal of Fish Biology 47: 50. doi:10.1111/j.1095-8649.1995.tb01872.x.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Preferably inhabits quiet shallow waters in mud-bottomed and sand-bottomed canals and ponds (Ref. 5723).  Feeds on small fish, crayfish, worms and insect larvae.  Quite popular with aquarists but not for aquaculturists because of its slow growth (Ref. 35237).  Maximum length 40 cm TL (Ref. 5723).  A highly esteemed food fish in South America (Ref. 44091).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: South America:  Amazon River basin in Peru, Colombia and Brazil; French Guiana.  Reported from Argentina (Ref. 9086).
dataObjects.references: Kullander, S.O. 2003 Cichlidae (Cichlids). p. 605-654. In R.E. Reis, S.O. Kullander and C.J. Ferraris, Jr. (eds.) Checklist of the Freshwater Fishes of South and Central America. Porto Alegre: EDIPUCRS, Brasil. (Ref. 36377)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Amazon River basin: Brazil, Colombia, French Guiana, Peru and Puerto Rico; introduced elsewhere, includiing southern Florida, U.S.A.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObjects.description: Dorsal spines (total): 12 - 14; Dorsal soft rays (total): 19 - 21;  Analspines: 3; Analsoft rays: 15 - 17

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObjects.title: Max. size
dataObjects.description: 45.7 cm TL (male/unsexed; (Ref. 40637)); max. published weight: 1,580 g (Ref. 40637)
dataObjects.references: IGFA 2001 Database of IGFA angling records until 2001. IGFA, Fort Lauderdale, USA. (Ref. 40637)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description: Large mouth with thick lips; 7 preopercular pores; first gill arch without lobe; gill rakers short and thick with many denticles; dorsal and anal fins bases densely scaled; many branched rays; body color dark with bright orange opercle margin and ventral parts of the lateral sides of the body; often a black rounded blotch with orange margin at caudal fin base (Ref. 35237).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Diseases
dataObjects.description: Bacterial Infections (general). Bacterial diseases

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeCycle
dataObjects.description: In captivity, both male and female clean a suitable spawning site - often a flat rock , or branches, or in a circular nest excavated in shallow water (Ref. 44091). Eggs (usually numbering in the thousands, Ref. 44091) are deposited and are guarded by both parents. Egg hatch in 3 or 4 days and parent move the fry to a shallow pit in the sand where they remain for 6 or 7 days (Ref. 7020).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Threats
dataObjects.description: Not Evaluated

dataObjects.title: File:Astronotus ocellatus.jpg
dataObjects.description: English: Oscar (Astronotus ocellatus), a popular aquarium fish from South America. Arabic: أوسكار (استرونوتوس وسيللاتوس)، من أسماك المياه العذبة في أمريكا الجنوبية و من أسماك الأحواض المائية ذات الشعبية French: Oscar (Astronotus ocellatus), un poisson d'eau douce d'Amérique du sud, très prisé pour l'aquarium.
